metadata.titleEn: Global long-term gap-free daily surface soil moisture dataset from 2002 to 2020
metadata.description: Soil moisture is an important state variable in the terrestrial water cycle and plays an important role in the study of land-atmosphere interactions, regional hydrological processes, and water resource management. Microwave remote sensing is an effective method for soil moisture monitoring and has many advantages, such as high sensitivity to soil moisture, all-weather observation capability, large spatial coverage, and frequent revisits. However, the global soil moisture datasets produced from satellite-based microwave observations usually suffer from gaps due to the satellite orbits, environmental factors, and retrieval algorithms, and these gaps affect their further applications in global climate change and hydrological process analysis. To solve this problem, we proposed a gap-filling method by applying the machine learning (Random Forest) algorithm in a pixel-by-pixel manner to reconstruct global surface soil moisture products, taking into account the nonlinear relationship between surface soil moisture and the related surface environmental variables. The gap-filling method was applied to the long-term global daily soil moisture dataset derived from AMSR-E and AMSR2 (NN-SM) (https://doi.org/10.11888/Soil.tpdc.270960), and a global daily gap-free surface soil moisture dataset from 2002 to 2020 was then generated accordingly. The accuracy of the reconstructed surface soil moisture dataset was evaluated using in situ surface soil moisture observations from sites in the International Soil Moisture Network (ISMN) and the Long-Term Agroecosystem Research (LTAR) network, and good accuracy was indicated with an ubRMSE of 0.051 m3/m3. Overall, the reconstructed surface soil moisture dataset retained the good characteristics of the original NN-SM product, such as high accuracy and reliable spatiotemporal pattern, while having the advantage of continuous spatiotemporal coverage, which makes it more suitable for further applications in the analysis of global surface soil moisture trends, land surface hydrological processes, and land-atmosphere energy and water exchanges, etc.
metadata.instructions: The dataset contains surface soil moisture and data flags, stored in geotiff format. The file name of soil moisture data is “reconstructed_sm_yyyydoy.tif”, where yyyy represents the year and ddd represents the Julian date. For example, “reconstructed_sm_2004001.tif” represents the global soil moisture distribution on the first day of 2004, and the corresponding file name of data flags is “reconstructed_sm_yyyydoy_flag.tif”. The data flags are as follows: “0” represents the original value of surface soil moisture from NN-SM; “1” represents the gap-filled value of surface soil moisture; “2” represents the pixels covered by water or snow/ice, and frozen soils. Data reading method: The data can be read by any software or computer language that can read geotiff format, such as ArcGIS, ENVI, IDL, Matlab and so on.

background: Soil moisture (SM) is considered as one of the most important factors in hydrology, ecology, meteorology, and soil science. Soil moisture data are mainly obtained by three methods: in situ observations, land surface model simulations, and satellite remote sensing observations. In recent years, with the continuous development of space technology, satellite remote sensing observation has become one of the most important means to obtain SM products for use at regional and global scales. The remote sensing-based SM is usually referred to as the volumetric soil water content in the surface layer (generally with depth less than 5 cm), hereafter referred to as surface soil moisture (SSM) in this study. Previous studies have shown that the surface soil moisture product from Soil Moisture Active Passive (SMAP) is currently the most accurate with ubRMSE close to 0.04 m3/m3. However, it has relatively short temporal coverage, i.e., from 2015 to present. Efforts have been made to improve the accuracy and the temporal coverage of remote sensing surface soil moisture by fusing different satellite data. However, due to the impacts of the satellite orbit, radio frequency interference, vegetation interference, presence of ice, and snow or frozen ground, the acquired surface soil moisture products always have gaps in many areas. Therefore, an effective strategy to reconstruct the missing data in the surface soil moisture product is required to improve the spatiotemporal integrity of the SM products.
research objective: Considering the critical role of spatio-temporally continuous surface soil moisture data and the capability of the machine learning method, this study attempts to generate a long-term surface soil moisture dataset at the global scale with spatiotemporal continuity. The main objectives are: (1) to develop a surface soil moisture reconstruction model using the Random Forest algorithm based on the correlation between surface soil moisture and various influencing factors of multiple surface environmental variables; (2) to generate a global spatiotemporal continuous daily gap-free surface soil moisture dataset from 2002 to 2020 by reconstructing the missing soil moisture data in the NN-SM product; (3) to demonstrate the reliability of the reconstructed gap-free surface soil moisture product by comparison with in situ observations.
challenges: However, soil moisture products produced from satellite observations have data gaps due to the limited capabilities of satellite orbit/swath and retrieval algorithms, which limit the regional and global applications of soil moisture data in hydrology and agriculture studies. The fractional number of valid observations in GDSMFD is 67.2%, and the fractional number of valid observations was low in high-altitude and high-latitude regions. This phenomenon makes it difficult to achieve spatial continuity in these surface soil moisture datasets and greatly hinders subsequent applications. Furthermore, the data gaps vary with time and locations, making it difficult to analyze surface soil moisture characteristics in specific regions and time periods.
methods: The workflow of our study method is shown in Figure 1. The overall structure of this study is divided into three parts: (1) selection of feature variables that are strongly associated with surface soil moisture and can serve as independent variables for the surface soil moisture gap-filling model; (2) model training and application to establish the surface soil moisture gap-filling model by training a machine learning algorithm to identify the relationship between surface soil moisture and other independent environmental features on a pixel-by-pixel basis to generate the gap-free SM dataset at the global scale (special pixels were excluded, e.g., water, snow, ice, frozen soils or others); and (3) validation of the results by comparison with the in situ observations to illustrate the reliability of the reconstructed surface soil moisture dataset.
dataset: The gap-filling method was applied to the NN-SM surface soil moisture product, which has a fraction of data gaps of around 50% globally on a multi-year average. A global daily gap-free surface soil moisture dataset from 2002 to 2020 was then generated. The accuracy of the reconstructed surface soil moisture dataset was evaluated using in situ observations of surface soil moisture at 12 sites from the International Soil Moisture Network (ISMN) and the Long-Term Agroecosystem Research (LTAR) network.
findings: The reconstructed values of several sub-regions after manually eliminating the original values were cross-verified with the original data, and this clearly demonstrated the reliability of the reconstruction method with the correlation coefficient (R) ranging between 0.770 and 0.918, the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) between 0.057 and 0.082 m3/m3, the unbiased Root Mean Square Error (ubRMSE) between 0.053 and 0.081 m3/m3, and Bias between −0.012 and 0.008 m3/m3. The results showed good accuracy in terms of R (0.610), RMSE (0.067 m3/m3), ubRMSE (0.045 m3/m3), and Bias (0.031 m3/m3). Overall, the reconstructed surface soil moisture dataset retained the characteristics of the NN-SM product, such as high accuracy and good spatiotemporal pattern.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that effectively addresses gaps in satellite-derived soil moisture datasets?
Example.Answer: A data collection method that effectively addresses gaps in satellite-derived soil moisture datasets is the use of a machine learning algorithm, such as the Random Forest algorithm, which reconstructs missing data by leveraging the correlation between soil moisture and other environmental variables.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using satellite remote sensing for soil moisture data collection, and how has it been addressed?
Example.Answer: A challenge in using satellite remote sensing for soil moisture data collection is the presence of data gaps due to limitations in satellite orbit and retrieval algorithms. This challenge has been addressed by developing a reconstruction model using machine learning techniques to generate a spatiotemporally continuous dataset.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of how datasets are validated using ground observations in soil moisture research?
Example.Answer: In soil moisture research, datasets are validated using ground observations by comparing the reconstructed soil moisture values with in situ observations from networks such as the International Soil Moisture Network (ISMN) and the Long-Term Agroecosystem Research (LTAR) network, ensuring the dataset's accuracy and reliability.

Definition.Question: What does 'spatiotemporal continuity' mean in the context of soil moisture datasets?
Definition.Answer: In the context of soil moisture datasets, 'spatiotemporal continuity' refers to the consistent and uninterrupted coverage of soil moisture data across both space and time. This involves generating a dataset that has no gaps in the data, ensuring that soil moisture information is available for every location and every time point within the specified range, which is crucial for comprehensive analysis in hydrology, ecology, and agriculture.

Definition.Question: What are some challenges associated with soil moisture data collection from satellite observations?
Definition.Answer: Challenges associated with soil moisture data collection from satellite observations include gaps in data due to limitations of satellite orbit, retrieval algorithms, and environmental interferences such as vegetation, ice, snow, and frozen ground. These gaps hinder the spatiotemporal continuity of datasets, complicating their use in regional and global hydrology and agriculture studies.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for surface soil moisture using in situ observations compare to those using satellite remote sensing observations in terms of spatiotemporal coverage and data gaps?
Comparison.Answer: In situ observations provide localized, high-accuracy soil moisture data but lack broad spatial coverage. Satellite remote sensing observations offer extensive spatial coverage and continuous monitoring over time. However, satellite data often have gaps due to limitations in satellite orbit, environmental factors, and retrieval algorithms, impacting their spatiotemporal integrity.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when generating a global surface soil moisture dataset using a Random Forest reconstruction model compared to relying solely on satellite remote sensing data?
Comparison.Answer: Generating a global dataset with a Random Forest reconstruction model addresses data gaps by using correlations with other environmental variables, improving spatiotemporal continuity. In contrast, relying solely on satellite data often results in significant data gaps due to satellite orbit limitations and environmental interferences, which hinder comprehensive global applications.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the effectiveness of machine learning techniques like the Random Forest algorithm in reconstructing missing data in soil moisture datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of the Random Forest algorithm for reconstructing missing data in soil moisture datasets suggests its potential in enhancing spatiotemporal integrity by identifying relationships between soil moisture and various environmental variables on a pixel-by-pixel basis. This method demonstrated reliability and accuracy, as indicated by correlation coefficients and RMSE values, in creating a gap-free dataset.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying trends might be observed in soil moisture data when integrating in situ observations with satellite remote sensing, and how does this integration enhance data accuracy?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating in situ observations with satellite remote sensing data may reveal trends that enhance spatial and temporal coverage, filling gaps left by satellite data alone. This integration allows for cross-validation and increases accuracy, as demonstrated by improved correlation and reduced errors (RMSE, ubRMSE) when comparing reconstructed values with original in situ data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes data gaps in surface soil moisture datasets obtained from satellite observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Data gaps in surface soil moisture datasets from satellite observations are caused by the limited capabilities of satellite orbit/swath, retrieval algorithms, and environmental interferences such as vegetation, ice, or snow, which restrict the availability of continuous data coverage.

Causal Consequence.Question: What potential outcomes can arise from the availability of a global spatiotemporal continuous soil moisture dataset for hydrology and agriculture studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The availability of a global spatiotemporal continuous soil moisture dataset can significantly enhance regional and global applications in hydrology and agriculture studies. It provides a comprehensive view of soil moisture variations, supporting better water resource management, improving understanding of land-atmosphere interactions, and facilitating more accurate climatic and hydrological modeling. The dataset's continuity and accuracy also enable more precise monitoring of soil moisture dynamics over time and space.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of developing a surface soil moisture reconstruction model using a machine learning algorithm in the context of spatio-temporal data continuity?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to generate a long-term surface soil moisture dataset at the global scale with spatiotemporal continuity by reconstructing missing data in the soil moisture product, which enhances the dataset's reliability for hydrological and agricultural applications.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to validate reconstructed soil moisture datasets with in situ observations from networks like ISMN and LTAR?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Validation with in situ observations is crucial to demonstrate the reliability and accuracy of the reconstructed gap-free surface soil moisture product, ensuring its applicability for regional and global hydrology and ecology studies.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in developing a soil moisture reconstruction model using machine learning?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves selecting feature variables that strongly associate with surface soil moisture, training a machine learning algorithm to identify relationships between soil moisture and these features on a pixel-by-pixel basis, and applying the model to generate a gap-free soil moisture dataset. Validation is then conducted by comparing the reconstructed data with in situ observations to ensure reliability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the accuracy of a global surface soil moisture dataset be evaluated using in situ observations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The accuracy can be evaluated by comparing the reconstructed surface soil moisture dataset with in situ observations from networks such as the International Soil Moisture Network (ISMN) and the Long-Term Agroecosystem Research (LTAR) network. Metrics such as correlation coefficient, Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), unbiased RMSE, and Bias are used to assess the dataset's reliability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological challenges need to be addressed when reconstructing missing data in surface soil moisture products?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges include dealing with data gaps due to satellite observation limitations, such as orbit/swath constraints and retrieval algorithm issues. Additionally, maintaining spatial continuity in regions with low fractional valid observations, such as high-altitude and high-latitude areas, is crucial. The varying nature of data gaps over time and location also complicates the analysis of soil moisture characteristics.

Enablement.Question: What machine learning techniques enable the reconstruction of missing soil moisture data in datasets for improved spatiotemporal integrity?
Enablement.Answer: The use of the Random Forest algorithm facilitates the reconstruction of missing soil moisture data by identifying the relationship between surface soil moisture and other independent environmental features on a pixel-by-pixel basis, thereby generating a global gap-free soil moisture dataset.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the integration of in situ observations enhance the validation and accuracy of soil moisture datasets?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of in situ observations enhances the validation and accuracy of soil moisture datasets by providing reference data for accuracy assessment, as demonstrated through comparisons with in situ observations from networks like the International Soil Moisture Network (ISMN) and the Long-Term Agroecosystem Research (LTAR) network, resulting in reliable reconstruction with high correlation and low error metrics.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in achieving spatial continuity in surface soil moisture datasets despite advancements in remote sensing technologies?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in achieving spatial continuity in surface soil moisture datasets arise due to data gaps caused by limited satellite orbit capabilities, retrieval algorithm limitations, and environmental interferences such as vegetation, ice, and snow. These factors result in incomplete datasets that hinder regional and global applications in hydrology and agriculture.

Expectation.Question: What could be the reasons for using machine learning methods like the Random Forest algorithm in reconstructing spatiotemporal soil moisture datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Machine learning methods like the Random Forest algorithm are used for reconstructing spatiotemporal soil moisture datasets due to their capability to model complex relationships between soil moisture and various environmental variables. These methods help fill data gaps by identifying patterns and correlations on a pixel-by-pixel basis, ensuring a more comprehensive dataset.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges do you perceive in achieving spatial continuity in global soil moisture datasets, particularly in high-altitude and high-latitude regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Achieving spatial continuity in global soil moisture datasets is challenged by data gaps due to satellite orbit limitations, radio frequency interference, and environmental factors such as vegetation and frozen ground. These issues are particularly pronounced in high-altitude and high-latitude regions, where the fractional number of valid observations is lower, making it difficult to maintain spatial continuity.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the critical factors to consider when developing a machine learning model for soil moisture data reconstruction?
Judgmental.Answer: Critical factors to consider include selecting feature variables strongly associated with soil moisture, ensuring the model can handle spatial and temporal variability, and validating the model with in situ observations. Excluding special pixels, such as water, snow, and ice, is also important to improve the model's applicability and accuracy in generating a gap-free soil moisture dataset.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out why the soil moisture data collection from satellites results in data gaps and how these gaps impact the use of the data in hydrology and agriculture studies.
Assertion.Answer: Soil moisture data collected from satellites have gaps due to the limited capabilities of satellite orbit/swath and retrieval algorithms. These gaps, which occur due to factors like radio frequency interference, vegetation interference, and the presence of ice or snow, limit the regional and global application of soil moisture data in hydrology and agriculture studies.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how machine learning can be used to reconstruct missing surface soil moisture data to ensure spatiotemporal continuity.
Assertion.Answer: Machine learning, particularly the Random Forest algorithm, is used to reconstruct missing surface soil moisture data by identifying the relationship between surface soil moisture and various influencing factors of multiple surface environmental variables on a pixel-by-pixel basis. This method generates a spatiotemporally continuous, gap-free dataset by using these correlations.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure why evaluating the reconstructed soil moisture dataset's accuracy with in situ observations is important.
Assertion.Answer: Evaluating the reconstructed soil moisture dataset's accuracy with in situ observations is important to demonstrate the reliability of the reconstructed dataset. This comparison helps to validate the results and ensure that the reconstructed values are accurate and maintain the characteristics of the original dataset, such as high accuracy and good spatiotemporal pattern.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore how machine learning algorithms can be utilized to improve the spatiotemporal continuity of soil moisture datasets by addressing data gaps due to satellite observation limitations.
Request/Directive.Answer: The Random Forest algorithm was employed to reconstruct a global spatiotemporal continuous daily gap-free surface soil moisture dataset from 2002 to 2020. The algorithm utilizes the correlation between surface soil moisture and various influencing factors of multiple surface environmental variables, effectively addressing data gaps caused by satellite observation limitations. This approach allows for the generation of a dataset with improved spatiotemporal coverage.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate the challenges associated with using remote sensing data for surface soil moisture measurement, particularly in high-altitude and high-latitude regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Remote sensing data for surface soil moisture measurement can have gaps due to the satellite orbit/swath and retrieval algorithms, which are particularly problematic in high-altitude and high-latitude regions. These gaps hinder the spatial continuity of datasets and complicate the analysis of soil moisture characteristics over specific regions and time periods.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection methods used to validate reconstructed surface soil moisture datasets and evaluate their accuracy.
Request/Directive.Answer: Reconstructed surface soil moisture datasets were validated using in situ observations from the International Soil Moisture Network (ISMN) and the Long-Term Agroecosystem Research (LTAR) network. These ground-based observations were used to evaluate the accuracy of the datasets, yielding correlation coefficients ranging between 0.770 and 0.918, and demonstrating good accuracy in terms of RMSE, ubRMSE, and Bias.
